tit.e: Jigatachigyo (provision of lands from a feudal government or domains to retainers as salary)
tit.cmt: 以下で、詳しく定義するので、 (provision of lands from a feudal government or domains to retainers as salary)を取りました。以下で出てくる「○○知行」用語は、jigatachigyoの表記に合わせ、-chigyoとせず、ハイフン無しの一語で統一しました。

sen.j: 地方知行（じがたちぎょう）とは、江戸時代に征夷大将軍あるいは藩主が家臣に対して禄として与える知行を所領（地方と呼ばれる土地）及びそこの付随する百姓の形で与え、支配させること。
sen.e: Jigatachigyo was the administrative system during Edo period that Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") or a lord of domain gave chigyo in the form of shoryo (territory) along with peasants lived on the territory to vassals as a stipend in order to rule the domain.

Jigatachigyo was the administrative form during Edo period that Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") or a lord of domain gave chigyo (enfeoffment, or the right to direct control of a certain asset) in the form of shoryo (territory) including the peasants living there to their vassals as a stipend and made them control it.

sen.e: Jigatachigyo was the administrative form during Edo period that Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") or a lord of domain gave chigyo (enfeoffment, or the right to direct control of a certain asset) in the form of shoryo (territory) including the peasants living there to their vassals as a stipend and made them control it.

sen.j: 特に将軍が大名に土地を与える場合には特に大名知行（だいみょうちぎょう）と呼ばれている。
sen.e: Jigatachigyo was called daimyo-chigyo especially when it was given to a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) by Shogun.
The form of territory provision to a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) by a shogun was especially called daimyochigyo.

sen.j: 一般的に地方知行を受けるのは上中級の江戸幕府旗本及び御家人、諸大名の上級家臣である。
sen.e: Generally, Jigatachigyo was given to high/middle-ranked hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and gokenin (shogunal retainers) in the Edo bakufu or to high-ranked vassals of each daimyo (a feudal lord).

sen.j: 彼らは地頭と呼ばれ、知行として与えられた土地（知行地）を知行所（ちぎょうしょ）もしくは給所（きゅうしょ）と呼んだ（なお、幕府御家人の場合は格上である旗本の知行地である給所と区別する意味で給地（きゅうち）と呼称させた）。
sen.e: They were called jito (manager and lord of manor), and given territory (chigyo) was called chigyosho (a land paid as a chigyo's salary, especially a domain of Samurai holding less 10,000 koku in the Edo period) or kyusho (incidentally, in the case of bakufu gokenin, given territory was called kyuchi in order to distinguish it from chigyochi belong to high-ranked hatamoto)

sen.j: また、知行は石高単位に応じて与えられたために実際の行政単位と合致しないことも少なくなく、1村を複数の地頭で分割する相給が行われることも珍しくなかった。
sen.e: Additionally, because chigyo was given according to the unit of kokudaka (a system for determining land value for tribute purposes in the Edo period), it often happened that kokudaka did not correspond to actual administrative unit, accordingly, it was a common practice to do aikyu to divide one village among several jitos.

sen.j: 知行を受けた家臣を「地頭」とは呼ばれているが、中世の地頭とは違って職務上の必要による例外を除けば、城下町（旗本・御家人の場合は江戸）に在住する義務を負っていた（例外として、仙台藩では各家臣が仙台城下町と知行地との間を参勤交代していた）。
sen.e: A vassal who was given chigyo was called 'jito', but unlike jito during the medieval period, he had an obligation to live in a castle town (Edo as for hatamoto and gokenin) except when he had some official duties (as an exceptional case, sankin-kotai was exercised in Sendai Domain, and vassals had to live between chigyo-chi and Sendai castle town alternately).

A vassal who was given chigyo was called 'jito', but unlike the jito of the medieval period, he had an obligation to live in a rural castle town (hatamoto and gokenin were obliged to live in Edo) except when he had some official duties (as an exceptional case, sankin-kotai [a system under which feudal lords in the Edo period were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo] was exercised in Sendai Domain, and vassals had to live alternately in chigyo-chi and Sendai castle town alternately).

sen.j: また、また旗本や大藩の上級家臣の中には独自の法制（地頭法）を持つ者もいたが、徴税権・司法権、その他の行政権などの所領に対する支配権（知行権）の行使は主君である将軍・大名によって規制されるのが一般的であり、時代が進むにつれてその傾向が強くなった（もっとも、所属する主家の方針や地頭である家臣の方針によってその強弱に格差があった）。
sen.e: Additionally, although some hatamoto or high-ranked vassal of taihan (large scale domain) had their unique legislation (law for jito), exercise of hegemony (chigyo-ken) over shoryo (territory) including tax collection right, judicial power and other administrative power was usually controlled by shogun or daimyo as a lord, and that tendency became stronger with the time (however, strength of the tendency was different depending on the policy of a master or a vassal (jito).

sen.j: これに対して所領ではなく蔵米の形で与える知行を蔵米知行と呼ぶ（なお、大名知行の場合、一部が蔵米知行である場合は存在したが、知行全てが蔵米支給であった大名は存在しなかった）。
sen.e: On the other hand, chigyo which was not a form of shyoryo but a form of kuramai (rice preserved in a depository by Edo Shogunate and domains) was called kuramaichigyo (a system which Bakufu or clans paid rice as a salary to vassals instead of providing chiko(enfeoffment) (concerning daimyo-chigyo, there was some cases that a part of chigyo was kuramaichigyo, but there was not such case that the whole chigyo was kuramaichigyo).

On the other hand, chigyo (enfeoffment) which was not given in a form of shoryo but in a form of kuramai (rice preserved in a depository by Edo Shogunate and domains) was called kuramaichigyo (in case of daimyochigyo, some daimyo received their part of chigyo in a form of kuramaichigyo, but there was no daimyo whose entire chigyo was provided in the form of kuramai).

tit.cmt: 以下の意味説明がわかりやすいように（「地方」をもとにした複合語だとわかるように）、Jikata-meshiage, Jikata-naoshiとハイフンを入れました。

sen.j: 将軍や大名が家臣の知行を地方知行から蔵米知行に改めることを「地方召上（じかためしあげ）」と呼び、逆に蔵米知行から地方知行に改めることを「地方直（じかたなおし）」と呼んだ。
sen.e: Change from jigatachigyo to kuramaichigyo conducted by shogun or daimyo was called 'jigatameshiage', whereas change from kuramaichigyo to jigatachigyo was called 'jigatanaoshi'.

Change of the chigyo's form from jigatachigyo to kuramaichigyo by a shogun or a daimyo was called 'jikata-meshiage' (territory expropriation), while the change from kuramaichigyo to jigatachigyo was called 'jikata-naoshi' (territory readjustment).
sen.cmt: 「地方召上（じかためしあげ）」：''jikata-meshiage' (territory expropriation)「地方直（じかたなおし）」：(territory readjustment)
sen.e: Change of the chigyo's form from jigatachigyo to kuramaichigyo by a shogun or a daimyo was called 'jikata-meshiage' (territory expropriation), while the change from kuramaichigyo to jigatachigyo was called 'jikata-naoshi' (territory readjustment).

sen.j: 伝統的に武士階層は土地（地方）をもって所領を与えられることを望んだことから、地方召上に懲罰的要素を含む場合や反対に地方直に恩賞的要素を含む場合もあった。
sen.e: The samurai class traditionally preferred to receive shoryo as the form of territory (jigata), accordingly, jigaatameshiage sometimes contained punitive meaning, in the opposite sense, jigatanaoshi sometimes contained reward meaning.

The samurai class traditionally preferred to receive shoryo as the form of territory (jikata); accordingly, jikata-meshiage sometimes contained a certain punitive sense, and on the contrary, jikata-naoshi sometimes implicates a kind of reward.

sen.e: The samurai class traditionally preferred to receive shoryo as the form of territory (jikata); accordingly, jikata-meshiage sometimes contained a certain punitive sense, and on the contrary, jikata-naoshi sometimes implicates a kind of reward.

sen.j: 江戸時代初期には諸藩においては地方知行を行う例が多く蔵米知行は下級家臣に限られていたが、次第に大名の支配権力と財政基盤の強化のために上級家臣に対しても地方召上を行って蔵米知行に変更されることが多くなった。
sen.e: In the early days of Edo period, jigatachigyo was generally conducted in each domain and kuramaichigyo was limited to lower-ranked vassals, but transfer to jigatameshiage for kuramaichigyo was gradually increased even for higher-ranking vassals in order to strengthen the hegemony of lord and financial base.

In the early Edo period, jigatachigyo (provision of land) was generally conducted in the domains and kuramaichigyo (stipend provision in rice) was limited to lower-ranked vassals, but later on, the domains gradually changed the provision form of chigyo to kuramaichigyo even for their higher-ranking vassals by carrying out jikata-meshiage in order to strengthen daimyo's authority and consolidate the territory and financial base of the domain.
sen.cmt: 構文、用語を少し変えました。
sen.e: In the early Edo period, jigatachigyo (provision of land) was generally conducted in the domains, while kuramaichigyo (stipend provision in rice) was limited to lower-ranked vassals; later on, however, the domains gradually changed the provision form of chigyo to kuramaichigyo even for their higher-ranking vassals by carrying out jikata-meshiage in order to strengthen the daimyo's authority and consolidate the territory and financial base of the domain.

sen.j: 元禄期の作とされる『土芥寇讎記』によれば、当時243の藩のうち地方知行が行われていたのは外様大名系の大藩を中心とした39藩に過ぎなかったとされている。
sen.e: According to "Dokai Koshuki " (1690 compilation of reports of 243 daimyo) which is said to be written during Genroku period, jigatachjgyo was conducted in only 39 domains, majority of which was domans of tozama daimyo (nonhereditary feudal lord), among 243 domains in those days.

According to "Dokai Koshuki, " a compilation of reports which is said to have been written in the Genroku era (1688-1707), jigatachigyo was conducted in only 39 domains out of the 243 domains in those days, and a majority of them were the domains of tozama daimyo (outside daimyo who were not hereditary vassals of the shogun).

sen.j: ただし、前述のように地方召上には懲罰的な意味合いを持つケースもあったために、移行の際のトラブルが御家騒動に発展する可能性もあった。

sen.j: これに対して、比較的余裕を有していた江戸幕府では地方直を行って旗本の知行を蔵米知行から地方知行に改めることでこれまでの働きに対する恩賞として、旗本たちの歓心買うとともに将軍への忠誠を高めようとした。
sen.e: Contrary to this, the Edo bakufu, which was relatively prosperous, tried to win the favor of hatamoto and so on as well as to raise their allegiance by transferring hatamono's chigyo from kuramaichigyo to jigatachigyo as Onsho (reward grants) for their achievements so far.

On the other hand, the Edo bakufu, which had relatively affluent resources, tried to win the favor of hatamoto, and at the same time, to raise their allegiance by changing the provision form of chigyo to hatamoto from kuramaichigyo to jigatachigyo, and applied jikata-naoshi to them in the name of the reward for their past achievements and services.

sen.j: 徳川家康の関東地方移封後に伴う天正19年（1591年）の所領の再配分と関ヶ原の戦いと大坂の陣の両戦後に行った親藩・譜代大名及び旗本に対する広範囲のな加増・転封についても地方直としての側面もある。
sen.e: There was an aspect of jigatanaoshi in re-division of shoryo which was done in 1591 along with changing the territory to Kanto region of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA as well as in the increase and changing of the territory which was conducted widely against Shinpan (Tokugawa's relatives), fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) and hatamoto after the Battle of Sekigahara and Osaka no Jin (The Siege of Osaka).

sen.e: The following measures that Ieyasu TOKUGAWA carried out have a certain aspect of jikata-naoshi: the redistribution of shoryo (his vassals' territories) after his transference to Kanto region; and the extensive increase and transfer of the territories in favor of Shinpan (Tokugawa's relatives), fudai daimyo (hereditary vassals to the Tokugawa family) and hatamoto of his side after the Battle of Sekigahara and Osaka no Jin (The Siege of Osaka).
sen.cmt: 構文を変えました。「旗本」は文意から「味方の旗本」hatamoto of his sideとしました。
sen.e: The following measures that Ieyasu TOKUGAWA carried out were somewhat similar to jikata-naoshi: the redistribution of shoryo (his vassals' territories) after his move to the Kanto region; and the extensive increase and transfer of territories in favor of Shinpan (Tokugawa's relatives), fudai daimyo (hereditary vassals to the Tokugawa family) and hatamoto who served on his side that took place after the Battle of Sekigahara and Osaka no Jin (The Siege of Osaka).

sen.j: しかし、江戸幕府が地方直を目的として大規模に行ったものとしては、寛永10年（1633年）と元禄10年（1697年）に行ったものである。
sen.e: However, large-scale performance aiming jigatanaoshi by the Edo bakufu was the ones in 1633 and in 1697.

sen.e: Opinions about the characteristic of jigatachigo differ among historians, but it can be broadly divided into two groups.

sen.j: ひとつは、土地で知行を与える行為を中世のものとみなし、地方知行を中世の制度の名残として次第にそこから脱却して近世的な蔵米知行に移行していった考える説である。
sen.e: One theory is that to give chigyo by the form of territory is considered to be a system in the medieval period and chigyo was gradually transferred to kuramaichigyo in the early-modern times while remaining the traces of jigatachigyo as a system during the medieval period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The first one is the theory that providing chigyo in a form of territory was a medieval practice and chigyo, which was a legacy of the medieval system, was gradually transferred to a form of kuramaichigyo in the early-modern times.

sen.e: The first one is the theory that providing chigyo in a form of territory was a medieval practice and chigyo, which was a legacy of the medieval system, was gradually transferred to a form of kuramaichigyo in the early-modern times.

sen.j: 次に、大名知行がその知行の全部あるいは一部分を必ず土地をもって与えていることから地方知行を近世幕藩体制の根幹とみなして蔵米知行はそれを補うものに過ぎないとする説である。
sen.e: The second theory is that jigatachigyo was the root of the shogunate system and also kuramaichigyo was no more than a supplementation, from the viewpoint that daimyochigyo was chigyo of which the whole or at least part was territory.

sen.e: The second theory argues that jigatachigyo was the basis of the shogunate system in the early-modern times and kuramaichigyo was no more than a supplementary system, based on the fact that in case of daimyochigyo the territory was indispensable and the entire or at least some part of chigyo was always given in this form.

sen.e: The second theory argues that jigatachigyo was the basis of the shogunate system in the early-modern times and kuramaichigyo was no more than a supplementary system, based on the fact that in case of daimyochigyo the territory was indispensable and the entire or at least some part of chigyo was always given in this form.

sen.j: なお、諸藩のうち松前藩のみは米の収穫のない土地を領有していたため、家臣に対してアイヌ民族との交易場であった商場を地方にかわる知行として与えていた。
sen.e: Incidentally, because only Matsumae Domain among domains held territory in which there was no yield from rice, Koekiba (hall of commerce) with the Ainu was given as a substitute of chigyo.
Among the domains, Matsumae Domain was the only domain in which there was no yield from rice crop, akinaiba, in other word, koekiba (trading right) with the Ainu was given as a substitute of chigyo.

sen.j: これを商場知行制（あきないばちぎょうせい）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: This is called akinaiba-chigyo system
